subject: Re: [junit] JUnit vs. Agitator
msgSnippet: I can t think of a _single_ situation in which it would be desirable to eliminate the need to write most JUnit tests . A feature without a JUnit test case
messageBody:
I can't think of a _single_ situation in which it would be desirable to
"eliminate the need to write most JUnit tests". A feature without a
JUnit test case doesnt' exist, as far as I'm concerned.
--
Stephen Smith, MEng (Wales).
http://www.stephen-smith.co.uk/

davek725 wrote:
> My company is currently doing TDD and using JUnit for our unit
> testing - both persistence testing and business logic testing. We
> are now looking at Agitator and trying to determine if, and how, it
> fits into our current practices. I was wondering how others have
> decided to use Agitator (or not use it). Some of the issues we are
> struggling with:
>
> 1. Agitator looks like it can eliminate the need to write most JUnit
> tests (except true persistence testing). The downside is that we
> would be left with only Agitator config files that contain our
> business logic assertions. This seems like a big leap to take, given
> that if Agitar goes away, we have no JUnit.
>
> 2. Agitator mocks and factories look easy to create, but look like
> they are only useful in the context of Agitator. I couldn't use them
> for other purposes (e.g. Fitnesse, JUnit).
>
> 3. Having my business logic tests in JUnit means they are in an
> understood format and things such as inputs and expected results are
> clearly visible and grouped with each test. My impression of
> Agitator is that this wouldn't be as clear.
>
